Dalian Liaoning 116318 China Hengli Petrochemical (Dalian) New Materials Technology Co., Ltd., Dalian 116318, Liaoning, China * Corresponding author. Iron-Vanadium (FeV) catalyst showed a unique catalytic activity for the selective oxidation of methanol to formaldehyde; however, due to its complex compositions, the identification of catalytic active sites still remains challenging, inhibiting the rational design of excellent FeV-based catalysts. Here, in this work, a series of FeV catalysts with various compositions, including FeVO4, isolated VO x , low-polymerized V n O x , and crystalline V2O5 were prepared by controlling the preparation conditions, and were applied to methanol oxidation to formaldehyde reaction. A FeV1.1 catalyst, which consisted of FeVO4 and low-polymerized V n O x species showed an excellent catalytic performance with a methanol conversion of 92.3% and a formaldehyde selectivity of 90.6%, which was comparable to that of conventional iron-molybdate catalyst. The results of CH3OH-IR, O2 pulse and control experiments revealed a crucial synergistic effect between FeVO4 and low-polymerized V n O x . It enhanced the oxygen supply capacity and suitable binding and adsorption strengths for formaldehyde intermediates, contributing to the high catalytic activity and formaldehyde selectivity. This study not only advances the understanding of FeV structure but also offers valuable guidelines for selective methanol oxidation to formaldehyde. Graphical Abstract The synergistic effect between FeVO4 and V n O x maybe the key to realize the high efficiency of oxidation of methanol to formaldehyde. Keywords Iron-vanadium Selective oxidation Methanol Formaldehyde Synergistic effect 1 Introduction Formaldehyde is an important bulk chemical, and over 90% of industrial formaldehyde is produced via the selective oxidation of methanol [1–5]. The conventional iron-molybdate as the primary catalyst has been widely applied in formaldehyde synthesis [6–8]. Meanwhile, it suffers unavoidable deactivation due to the loss of active Mo species [9–12]. Thus, there is an urgent need to develop novel non-iron-molybdate catalysts with superior catalytic performance and stability. Vanadium-based (V-based) catalysts exhibit excellent catalytic activity and stability in oxidation reactions due to their unique redox properties and resistance to loss [13–16]. Iron-vanadium (FeV), as a typical catalyst in V-based catalysts, has been found to catalyze the selective oxidation of methanol to formaldehyde [17]. Wachs et al. [18] developed bulk FeV catalysts, achieving 83% formaldehyde selectivity. Andersson et al. [9] prepared Al-modified FeV catalyst, which could achieve 90% methanol conversion and 90% formaldehyde selectivity. Spinel-type FeV catalysts exhibited a comparable catalytic activity with a formaldehyde selectivity of 90% [19]. Although various FeV catalysts have been found to show unique catalytic activity for the selective oxidation of methanol, the identification of catalytic active sites still remains controversial due to the complexity of FeV structure [20]. For FeV catalysts, the presence of bulk iron vanadate (FeVO4) phase is often accompanied by the formation of various V species on the surface, including isolated VO x , low-polymerized V n O x , and crystalline V2O5, etc., which is the key to influence the catalytic activity [21–24]. Andersson et al. [9,25] reported that the Fe-O-V linkages formed by Fe substitution of V-O-V was the active sites for selective oxidation of methanol to formaldehyde by the inhibition of overoxidation. Wachs et al. [18] demonstrated that low-polymerized V n O x originated from FeVO4 phase was the catalytic active sites. He et al. [26] proposed that the true catalytic active phase in TiO2-supported FeVO4 catalysts was the VO x species enriched on the surface of highly dispersed FeVO4. Therefore, to identify catalytic active sites is benefit for designing FeV catalysts with excellent catalytic activity, but is still challenging. In this work, various FeV catalysts were prepared successfully by controlling the preparation conditions (pH value and V/Fe molar ratio) via a co-precipitation method to obtain distinct V species. A FeV catalyst with an excess of V (FeV1.1) showed an excellent catalytic performance with a methanol conversion of 92.3% and a formaldehyde selectivity of 90.6%, which was comparable to that of iron-molybdate catalyst. A combination of X-ray diffraction (XRD), Raman, X-ray fluorescence (XRF), and ultraviolet-visible (UV-vis) results indicated the coexistence of active low-polymerized V n O x with FeVO4 phase. The results of CH3OH-IR, O2 pulse and control experiments revealed a synergistic effect between low-polymerized V n O x and FeVO4 phase, which enhanced the strong oxygen supply capacity and suitable binding and adsorption strengths for formaldehyde intermediates, contributing to the high catalytic activity and formaldehyde selectivity. 2 Experimental 2.1 Materials Fe(NO3)3·9H2O (99.9%) and Ammonia solution (25 wt%), were purchased from Tianjin Damao Chemical Reagent Co. Ltd. NH4VO3 (99%) was purchased from Aladdin Reagent Co. Ltd. Oxalic acid (98%) was purchased from Meryer Reagent Co., Ltd. γ-Al2O3 (99.99%, S BET = 157 m2/g) was purchased from Macklin Reagent Co., Ltd. The ultrapure water was produced by Milli-Q Advantage A10. All reagents require no further purification. 2.2 Catalyst preparation The FeV catalysts were prepared by coprecipitation method, as reported in the literature [27]. Firstly, Fe(NO3)3·9H2O (24.8 mmol, 10 g) and NH4VO3 (24.8 mmol, 2.9 g) were dispersed in ultrapure water respectively. The temperature of the NH4VO3 solution was 50 °C while that of the Fe(NO3)3 solution was room temperature. After that, the Fe(NO3)3 solution was slowly dropped to NH4VO3 solution and then, 10 wt% ammonia was slowly added dropwise to the mixture until the pH reached a predetermined value. In turn, the mixture was stirred at 30 °C for 30 min at 500 r/min. The resulting precipitate was recovered by filtration and multiple washing, then dried in an oven at 100 °C for 6 h and calcined in a muffle furnace at 580 °C for 6 h. A preparation yield (PYFeV) was defined as follows: (1) PYFeV = M(FeV)act/M(FeV)theo where M(FeV)act is the actual weight of catalysts, and M(FeV)theo is the theoretical weight of catalysts. The aV/Al2O3 catalysts were prepared via incipient wetness impregnation method, as reported in the literature [22]. NH4VO3 and oxalic acid [NH4VO3/oxalic acid = 0.5 (molar ratio)] were dissolved in ultrapure water and impregnated with γ-Al2O3 support (2 mL/g Al2O3). After impregnation, the catalysts were dried overnight at 100 °C and then calcined at 500 °C for 2 h. The prepared catalysts were named as aV/Al2O3, where a is the weight ratio of V/γ-Al2O3. The 4 wt% and 8 wt% V/Fe2O3 catalysts were prepared via traditional wet impregnation method [28]. NH4VO3 was completely dissolved in water assisted with the addition of oxalic acid. Then the Fe2O3 was added into the above solution obtained a muddy mixture. Finally, the additional desiccation at 80 °C overnight and calcination at 500 °C for 3 h were carried out one after another to obtain the final product of V/Fe2O3. 2.3 Catalytic reaction Prior to the catalytic testing, the catalyst was processed into pellets, ground, and sieved through a 40–60 mesh. Typically, 0.9 mL of the catalyst granules were loaded in a quartz reactor. Quartz wool was employed to secure the catalyst bed within the reactor tube appropriately. The catalysts were then heated at 230 °C in flowing feed gas CH3OH/O2/N2, gas hourly space velocity (GHSV) = 9000 h–1. Products were cooled and collected in a trap with the water as absorption liquid. The gas products were analyzed using a Shimadzu gas chromatography (GC). Formaldehyde was analyzed using the sodium sulfite method. Formic acid was analyzed using high-performance liquid chromatography (HPLC) and other products were analyzed using an Agilent gas chromatography (GC). The carbon balance was typically higher than 90%. The methanol conversion (X MeOH), FA selectivity (S FA), and FA yield (Y FA) were calculated via the following equations: (2) X MeOH = N(c)products/N(c)feed × 100% (3) S FA = N(c)FA/N(c)products × 100% (4) Y FA = N(c)FA/N(c)feed where N(c)products is the number of moles of carbon atoms in all products, and N(c)feed is the number of moles of carbon atoms in feed gas, and N(c)FA is the number of moles of carbon atoms of formaldehyde. 2.4 Characterization O2 pulse experiments were conducted on Temperature-Programmed Desorption-Mass Spectrometry (TPD-MS). The output gas was analyzed on ThermoStar GSD320 mass spectrometer. Typically, 0.2 g of the catalyst was heated at 230 °C for 5 min under MeOH flow and then 400 µL of 21 vol% O2/N2 gas were pulsed into the system every 90 s. The CH3OH-IR spectra of catalysts were obtained with a Thermo Nicolet iS50 Fourier transform infrared spectroscopy (FTIR) spectrometer. The samples were initially pressed into self-supporting thin wafers, which were then placed into a quartz cell and dehydrated to remove adsorbed moisture by heating up to 300 °C for 0.5 h in He. The spectra were recorded from 4000 to 400 cm–1 with an optical resolution of 4 cm–1 and obtained as follows: Initially, excess CH3OH vapor was introduced by He at room temperature for 1 h, then flushed with flowing He for another 1 h to remove trace amounts of CH3OH present in the line and possibly weakly adsorbed methanol. Subsequently, the atmosphere was changed to 30% O2/He, while the temperature was increased at a rate of 10 °C/min to various temperature points between 100 °C and 320 °C, and held for 10 min for reaction. Finally, the spectra were obtained by subtracting the background spectrum (obtained with decontaminated wafers before CH3OH adsorption at each temperature) from the measured sample spectra. 3 Results and discussion Firstly, FeV catalysts were prepared by co-precipitation method at a fixed feed molar ratio (V/Fe = 1:1) while the pH was in the range of 1.7–7.0. Their structures were characterized by XRF, XRD, UV-Vis and Raman and the results are shown in Fig. 1 . The preparation yields of the catalysts as well as the V/Fe molar ratios (hereinafter abbreviated as V/Fe) calculated using XRF measurements are shown in Fig. 1(a). When the the pH of synthesis system was increased from 1.7 to 3.0, the V/Fe decreased from 1.3 to 1.0, while the preparation yield increased from 62.5% to 96.0%, indicating that the increase of pH favors the precipitation of Fe ions into the catalyst with maintaining V species. When the pH was further increased to 7.0, V/Fe remained at about 1.0, the preparation yield was similar and stable above 90%, which proved that the composition of the catalysts tended to be stabilized and the pH was no longer a key factor in regulating the catalyst composition. The XRD results showed that all these FeV catalysts showed characteristic diffraction peaks at 2θ = 16.5°, 25.0°, 27.1°, 27.6°, and 33.3°, which were attributed to the presence of the FeVO4 phase (PDF#38-1372). Only for FeV catalyst prepared at pH as 1.7, besides FeVO4 phase, V2O5 phase (PDF#45-1074) was also observed due to the presence of characteristic diffraction peaks at 2θ = 12.4°, 18.9°, 26.5°, and 28.9°. These results indicated that the FeV catalysts with pristine FeVO4 phase and composite of FeVO4 and crystalline V2O5 could be obtained by controlling pH values. It was furtherly verified by the Raman results (Fig. 1(c)). All FeV catalysts exhibited Raman vibrations bands at 971, 931, 908, 736, 660, 631, 374, and 326 cm–1, which were attributed to the presence of the FeVO4 phase [18]. Similarly, for the FeV catalysts prepared at pH as 1.7, the Raman spectra also showed bands at 994, 696, and 145 cm–1, attributed to the characteristic vibrations of V2O5 crystals. It was noteworthy that for the Raman spectrum of FeV catalyst prepared at pH as 1.7 and 2.0, a new band at 1020 cm–1 was also observed which was assigned to the characteristic bands attributed to the stretching vibration of terminal mono V=O band of the surface low-polymerized V n O x species. UV-vis diffuse reflectance spectra showed that the absorption bands corresponding to the FeVO4 structure were observed at 492 nm for all catalysts. In contrast to pure Fe2O3, no wide absorption bands belonging to Fe2O3 were observed in the 440–600 nm range, demonstrating that Fe segregation did not occur in all FeV catalysts due to an excess of V species (V/Fe > 1.0) (Fig. 1(d)). A combination of XRD, UV-Vis, Raman and XRF results showed that the preparation yield and catalyst composition can be controlled by adjusting pH to give a pristine FeVO4 (FeV1.0) and FeV catalysts with excess V species (FeV1.0-1.33), which consisted of FeVO4, crystalline phase or/and surface low-polymerized V n O x species. Further preparation was focused on the effects of the feed V/Fe molar ratio on the structure of FeV catalysts. The feed V/Fe molar ratio was controlled ranging from 0.3 to 4.0. The preparation yield along with XRF, XRD, UV-vis and Raman characterization results are shown in Fig. S1. The results of XRF and preparation yield with the V/Fe showed that the actual V/Fe of the catalyst was consistent with the feed molar ratio when the feed V/Fe ≥ 1.0, with high preparation yield of 94.6%–98.3%. Continuing to increase the feed V/Fe to 4.0, the actual V/Fe of the catalyst decreased to 1.4 and then maintained around it, while the preparation yield constantly decreased to 39.7%, which indicated that excess V species did not enter the catalyst (Fig. S1(a)). XRD results showed that all the prepared catalysts contained FeVO4 phase. When the feed V/Fe < 1.0 (FeV0.3 and FeV0.5) with excess Fe species, characteristic diffraction peaks at 2θ = 24.1°, 33.2°, and 35.6° attributed to Fe2O3 phase (PDF#33-0664) were observed (Fig. S1(b)). It was also confirmed by UV-Vis and Raman results (Figs. S1(c), (d)). For FeV1.0 catalyst, only FeVO4 phase was found, while FeV1.4 with excess V species, V2O5 crystalline phase could be observed besides FeVO4 phase in the XRD and Raman results. In order to create dispersed V species that have not yet aggregated and crystallized into V2O5 state, the FeV catalysts were further finely tuned by adjusting the feed V/Fe between 1.0 and 2.0, and a series of characterizations were carried out, with the results shown in Fig. 2 . As the feed V/Fe was gradually increased from 1.2 to 1.8, the preparation yield decreased from 91.1% to 80.6%, and the corresponding catalyst actual V/Fe increased from 1.05 to 1.4 (Fig. 2(a)). XRD results showed that only the characteristic diffraction peaks of FeVO4 were observed for FeV1.05-1.3 catalysts, while the two phases of FeVO4 and V2O5 coexisted for FeV1.3 and FeV1.4 catalysts (Fig. 2(b)). UV-Vis results confirmed that no significant Fe2O3 segregation occurred in all catalysts (Fig. 2(c)). It is worth noting that surface structure was deeply revealed by Raman spectra (Fig. 2(d) and (e)). For FeV1.05 and FeV1.08 catalysts with a little vanadium excess, the characteristic vibrational bands of V=O attributed to isolated VO x sites appeared at 1017 cm-1 besides that of FeVO4. For FeV1.1 catalyst, the characteristic vibration of V=O shifted to 1020 cm–1, which was assigned to low-polymerized V n O x species. This variation was consistent with the previously observed trend of Raman characteristics of V species, that is, during the aggregation of V species from isolated state to low-polymerized state, the location of the V=O vibration band will shift, and usually move towards a higher wavenumber [29–31]. This indicated that when the content of V in FeV catalysts increased gradually, the VO x species had clustered to form low-polymerized V n O x species. For FeV1.2-1.4 catalysts, the characteristic bands attributed to the crystalline V2O5 were observed along with the detection of V n O x , and it was hypothesized that aggregation of excess V n O x species occurred to form the V2O5 phase. Raman spectra of typical FeV catalysts after dehydration treatment were given in Fig. S2, which excluded the possibility of hydration affecting V species under ambient condition. Based on these above-mentioned results, the composition and structure of FeV catalysts were controlled by adjusting the preparation conditions, including pH values and feed V/Fe molar ratios. The catalysts were classified into the following categories according to the type of vanadium sites contained: (1) Composite of FeVO4 and Fe2O3; (2) Pure phase FeVO4; (3) Composite of FeVO4 and isolated VO x ; (4) Composite of FeVO4 and low-polymerized V n O x ; (5) Composite of FeVO4 and crystalline V2O5 (Table 1 ). Then, the above typical FeV catalysts were applied in the selective oxidation of methanol to formaldehyde, and the reaction results are shown in Fig. 3 and Fig. S3. The FeV0.5 catalyst with Fe2O3 aggregation exhibited higher methanol conversion (99.9%) than that of the FeV1.0 with pure FeVO4 (80.0%), indicating that promotion of Fe2O3 phase in catalytic activity. On the other hand, the high catalytic activity resulted in the over oxidation of methanol to CO x (Fig. S3). Similarly, the presence of little vanadium excess also improved the methanol conversion to 99.9% and 92.3% for FeV1.05 and FeV1.1 catalysts, respectively. The products distribution suggested a superior formaldehyde selectivity on FeV1.1 catalyst (90.6%) than that on FeV1.05 catalyst (81.0%), due to the exhibition of over oxidation to CO x (Fig. S3). When utilized FeV1.4 as the catalyst with far excess vanadium, although the higher selectivity of formaldehyde (94.6%) was maintained, the methanol conversion decreased significantly to 42.5%, presumably due to the segregation of V2O5 crystalline phase, reducing the effective exposure of active V species. These results reveal that the FeV1.1 catalyst consisted of FeVO4 and low-polymerized V n O x showed a superior formaldehyde selectivity with a comparable conversion. The catalytic performances of FeV1.1, FeV1.05 and FeV1.4 catalysts were evaluated at various temperatures ranging from 190 to 240 °C (Fig. S4). Upon comparing the results of this catalytic reaction over these three catalysts, it was found that both the conversion and the selectivity increased for all the reaction temperatures over FeV1.1 (Fig. S4(a)), while the selectivity started to decrease when the conversion was higher than 45.4% at 210 °C due to the overoxidation over FeV1.05 (Fig. S4(b)). It suggested the superior catalytic activity of FeV1.1 to that of FeV1.05 for the selective conversion of methanol to formaldehyde. For FeV1.4 catalyst, the DMM (methylal) was found as the major by-product at low conversions, while the formaldehyde selectivity constantly increased with the conversion. In order to exclude the effect of different specific surface area of the catalysts, the BET surface area was detected and the activity was normalized to the specific surface area. The MeOH consumption rate was calculated from the GHSV and conversion (Table 2 ). With a similar MeOH consumption rate of 1.04 ~1.06 mmolmethanol/(h·m2), formaldehyde on FeV1.05 was more likely to be peroxided to HCOOH and CO x compared with FeV1.1. For FeV1.4, it showed a comparable formaldehyde selectivity with FeV1.1 but required a higher reaction temperature (230 vs. 210 °C). These results confirmed that the presence of isolated VO x species contributed to a high activity but led to an overoxidation of formaldehyde, while the presence of V2O5 gave a high formaldehyde but its activity is insufficient. By contrast, the presence of low-polymerized V n O x species provides a satisfied methanol conversion and formaldehyde, and considered as an essential species for the selective oxidation of methanol to formaldehyde. Further to understand the catalytic role of low-polymerized VnO x species in the catalytic oxidation of methanol to formaldehyde, V/Al2O3 catalysts with low-polymerized V n O x without the presence of FeVO4 were prepared according to the literature [30]. The formation of low-polymerized V n O x species were detected by Raman spectra (Fig. S5). The characteristic band at 1020 cm–1 belonging to low-polymerized V n O x was observed when the vanadium loading was 12% (12V/Al2O3) (Fig. S5(a)). It has been reported that vanadium oxide tends to exist in low-polymerized form on the carrier when the density of VO x on the Al2O3 surface is 8–9 V/nm2 [21]. The specific surface area of γ-Al2O3 used in this study was 157 m2/g, and the VO x density of 12V/Al2O3 was calculated to be 9 V/nm2, which verified the presence of surface low-polymerized V n O x under this condition. Meanwhile, V2O5 related characteristic bands were also observed in 12V/Al2O3, indicating that some V species aggregated to form crystalline V2O5 under this condition [22]. Applying 12V/Al2O3 to catalyze the methanol oxidation to formaldehyde reaction, the methanol conversion and formaldehyde selectivity were 96.2% and 68.7%, respectively (Fig. S5(b)). All of them were much lower than that of FeV1.1, excluding the excellent catalytic activity of solely low-polymerized V n O x . The same result was also demonstrated by reaction on V/Fe2O3 catalysts (Fig. S6). It suggested a possible synergistic catalysis of low-polymerized V n O x and FeVO4 to the efficient and selective preparation of formaldehyde. Based on the preferred catalyst FeV1.1, the reaction conditions for the selective oxidation of methanol to formaldehyde were optimized (Fig. 4 ). When the temperature increased from 210 to 250 °C, the methanol conversion increased from 36.4% to 99.9%, and the formaldehyde selectivity decreased from 91.7% to 42.9%. With increasing the GHSV from 6000 to 12000 h–1, the methanol conversion decreased from 94.8% to 86.7%, while the formaldehyde selectivity increased from 80.7% to 92.1%. The results showed that the optimal conditions for the reaction were 230 °C, GHSV = 9000 h–1, and the methanol conversion rate and formaldehyde selectivity were up to 92.3% and 90.6% respectively, which were comparable to the performance of industrial iron molybdate catalysts and showed potential for practical applications. Under the optimal reaction conditions, the stability of FeV1.1 catalyst was tested in a continuous reaction and the result was shown in Fig. S7. For the whole stability test, the formaldehyde selectivity remained 84%–92%. The methanol conversion showed a decrease from 95% to 84% after reaction for ~155 h, while it could be recovered by raising the temperature for 3 °C. After reaction for 180 h, the spent FeV1.1 catalyst (FeV1.1-S) was collected and characterized carefully by XRF, UV-vis, XRD, and Raman. Different from conventional FeMo catalyst, there was no remarkable vanadium lose and Fe2O3 segregation, which verified by XRF and UV-Vis results, suggesting its loss resistance (Table S1 and Fig. S8(a)). It indicated no remarkable structural collapse from the XRD results (Fig. S8(b)). It was noteworthy that an aggregation of low-polymerized V n O x species to crystalline V2O5 was found from Raman results, which probably led to the decrease of methanol conversion (Fig. S8(c)). The reaction process of methanol oxidation on FeV1.1 was tracked through CH3OH-IR, and FeV1.05 and FeV1.4 were simultaneously characterized as comparisons to explore the catalytic effects of isolated VO x , low-polymerized V n O x , and crystalline V2O5 (Figs. 5(a)–(c) ). Chemically adsorbed methanol species and methoxyl species (–CH3O*) produced by methanol dissociated were observed at 2825–2981 cm–1 on all three catalysts, and the intensity decreased with increasing temperature [18]. With the decrease of peak intensity assigned to –CH3O*, the stretching vibration of carbonyl group (C=O) at 1678 cm–1 increased by the transformation of –CH3O* to –C=O* and then decreased due to the desorption of aldehyde intermediates. Besides, the stretching vibration peaks of HCOOH were located around 1560 and 1360 cm−1 (Fig. S9), and the peak at ~1192 cm−1 was assigned to the –CH3O* symmetric stretching mode. These results demonstrated that in the process of methanol oxidation to formaldehyde, methoxyl and formate species appeared as intermediates [32–34]. The intensity of ν(C=O) at different temperatures was sorted out and normalized to obtain Fig. 5(d). According to the results, FeV1.1 consisted of FeVO4 and low-polymerized V n O x showed a trend of carbonyl strength change. The aldehyde intermediates formed at a high temperature (> 170 °C) but desorbed at a low temperature (~270 °C). FeV1.4 consisted of FeVO4 and crystallized V2O5 showed a similar result. Different from them, the FeV1.05 catalyst consisted of FeVO4 and isolated VO x could generate aldehyde intermediates at low temperatures (~130 °C), but should desorb completely at high temperature, suggesting a strong binding effect on aldehyde intermediates, leading to an over oxidation to CO x . These results reveal that the superior formaldehyde selectivity over FeV1.1 arose from the suitable strength for aldehyde intermediates binding. Fig. 6 showed the O2 pulse curves and H2-TPR results of FeV catalysts to investigate the redox properties of these catalysts. At the reaction temperature of 230 °C, the O2 consumption of FeV1.1 catalyst was 69 μmol/g, indicating the presence of the most active oxygen sites on its surface (Fig. 6(a)). Since the methanol oxidation reaction on V-based catalysts proceeds via the Mars-van Krevelen mechanism, the surface vanadium sites use bulk-phase lattice oxygen to oxidize the surface reaction intermediates to HCHO, and the consumed lattice oxygen is replenished by gas phase O2 [18,23]. Therefore, the FeV1.1 surface can capture the largest amount of oxygen and complete the MvK cycle with the best catalytic activity. For comparison, the O2 adsorption of the catalyst FeV1.4 consisted of FeVO4 and crystalline V2O5 was only 45 μmol/g, indicating the poor capability for O2 adsorption. It might be due to the aggregation of the excess V species in FeV1.4 catalyst, which reduced the effective exposure of the active vanadium sites, and thus decreased the methanol conversion in the methanol catalytic oxidation to formaldehyde (Fig. 6(b)). The O2 adsorption for the FeV1.05 catalyst was 50 μmol/g, which was at a moderate level to catalyze the realization of the methanol redox cycle (Fig. 6(c)). These results were also confirmed by H2-TPR (Fig. 6(d)). It showed that two main desorption peaks at 499 and 575 °C were observed in the profile of FeV1.05, which was ascribed to a combination of Fe3+ to Fe2+ and V5+ to V4+ and the reduction of Fe2+ to Fe0 as well as V5+ to V3+, respectively [35]. These two reduction peaks shifted to higher temperatures for FeV1.4 (512 and 585 °C, respectively), which might be due to the difficulty in the reduction of crystalline V2O5. These results reveal that the excellent oxygen supply capacity of FeV1.1 catalyst probably contributed to the high methanol conversion. 4 Conclusions A series of FeV catalysts with different compositions were prepared by co-precipitation method by controlling the preparation conditions (pH value and V/Fe molar ratio): (1) pure phase FeVO4; (2) Composite of FeVO4 and Fe2O3; (3) Composite of FeVO4 and isolated VO x ; (4) Composite of FeVO4 and low-polymerized V n O x ; (5) Composite of FeVO4 and crystalline V2O5, and were applied to methanol oxidation to formaldehyde reaction. The results showed that the composite system FeV1.1 consisting of low-polymerized V n O x and FeVO4 with stronger oxygen supply capacity and suitable binding effect on formaldehyde adsorbed species had excellent methanol conversion (92.3%) and formaldehyde selectivity (90.6%), which was comparable to that of conventional iron molybdate catalysts. Combined with the characterization results, it is speculated that the synergistic catalysis of FeVO4 and V n O x may be the key to achieve efficient methanol conversion and selective formaldehyde production, and the activity is comparable to that of traditional iron molybdate catalysts. The results of O2 pulse experiments and CH3OH-IR showed that its excellent catalytic activity and formaldehyde selectivity were due to its excellent oxygen supply capacity and suitable binding and adsorption capacity for formaldehyde intermediates. In contrast, VO x species tend to peroxidize products to CO due to strong binding to formaldehyde intermediates. However, crystalline V2O5 has limited exposure of active V species and covers part of iron vanadate species, which hinders the adsorption and activation of methanol and reduces the conversion. This study provides a new idea for the design of high-performance catalysts for methanol oxidation to formaldehyde, and deepens the understanding of FeV surface active sites and catalytic mechanisms. coredata.dc:description: Iron-Vanadium (FeV) catalyst showed a unique catalytic activity for the selective oxidation of methanol to formaldehyde; however, due to its complex compositions, the identification of catalytic active sites still remains challenging, inhibiting the rational design of excellent FeV-based catalysts. Here, in this work, a series of FeV catalysts with various compositions, including FeVO4, isolated VO x , low-polymerized V n O x , and crystalline V2O5 were prepared by controlling the preparation conditions, and were applied to methanol oxidation to formaldehyde reaction. A FeV1.1 catalyst, which consisted of FeVO4 and low-polymerized V n O x species showed an excellent catalytic performance with a methanol conversion of 92.3% and a formaldehyde selectivity of 90.6%, which was comparable to that of conventional iron-molybdate catalyst. The results of CH3OH-IR, O2 pulse and control experiments revealed a crucial synergistic effect between FeVO4 and low-polymerized V n O x . It enhanced the oxygen supply capacity and suitable binding and adsorption strengths for formaldehyde intermediates, contributing to the high catalytic activity and formaldehyde selectivity. This study not only advances the understanding of FeV structure but also offers valuable guidelines for selective methanol oxidation to formaldehyde.
